description:
Example how to use TheiaScene:

from yt.visualization.volume_rendering.theia.scene import TheiaScene
from yt.visualization.volume_rendering.theia.algorithms.front_to_back import FrontToBackRaycaster

from yt.visualization.volume_rendering.transfer_functions import ColorTransferFunction
from yt.visualization.color_maps import *

import subprocess as sp

import numpy as np

def scale_func(v, mi, ma):
      return  np.minimum(1.0, (v-mi)/(ma-mi) + 0.0)

bolshoi = "/home/bogert/log_densities_1024.npy"
density_grid = np.load(bolshoi)

ts = TheiaScene(volume = density_grid, raycaster = FrontToBackRaycaster(size = (1920,1080) ))

mi, ma = 0.0, 3.6
bins = 5000
tf = ColorTransferFunction( (mi, ma), bins)
tf.map_to_colormap(0.5, ma, colormap="spring", scale_func = scale_func)
ts.source.raycaster.set_transfer(tf)

ts.source.raycaster.set_density_scale(0.03)
ts.source.raycaster.set_brightness(2.3)
ts.camera.zoom(30.0)

FFMPEG_BIN = "ffmpeg"
pipe = sp.Popen([ FFMPEG_BIN,
        '-y', # (optional) overwrite the output file if it already exists
        '-f', 'rawvideo',
        '-vcodec','rawvideo',
        '-s', '1920x1080', # size of one frame
        '-pix_fmt', 'rgba',
        '-r', '9.97', # frames per second
        '-i', '-', # The input comes from a pipe
        '-an', # Tells FFMPEG not to expect any audio
        #'-vcodec', 'dnxhd', '-b:v', '220M',
        '-vcodec', 'libx264', '-preset', 'ultrafast', '-qp', '0',# '-b:v', '220M',
        '-pix_fmt', 'yuv420p',
        'bolshoiplanck2.mkv' ],
        stdin=sp.PIPE,stdout=sp.PIPE)


#ts.source.surface.bounds = (1920,1080)
for k in range (0,50) :
    ts.update()
    ts.camera.rotateX(0.01)
    ts.camera.rotateZ(0.01)
    ts.camera.rotateY(0.01)
    ts.camera.zoom(0.01)

    array = ts.source.get_results()

    array.tofile(pipe.stdin)

pipe.terminate()
title: CUDA Volume Renderer

content.html: I guess that wasn't a good place to put the example..

content.raw: I forgot to mention. This is dependent on pyCUDA being installed. Also the environmental variable CUDA_SAMPLES needs to be set correctly to point to cuda/samples/common/inc this may be in various locations on the server machine.
content.html: I forgot to mention. This is dependent on pyCUDA being installed. Also the environmental variable CUDA_SAMPLES needs to be set correctly to point to cuda/samples/common/inc this may be in various locations on the server machine.

content.raw:
Writing docs is pretty straightforward.  I just updated the documentation on how to do it in yt 3.0 here: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/developing/developing.html#how-to-write-documentation .  The easiest way to write a doc is to look at a previous doc and use it as a template.  

For documenting this new functionality, what I would do is just append your information at the end of the "visualizing/volume_rendering.rst" file.  This file is somewhat out of date and is going to be updated soon, but this seems like the obvious location for you to describe your new methods.  Just a short description of how to use this functionality and how it works.

Then, if you stick your example script (that you included above) in a cookbook recipe in the cookbook/ directory, perhaps call it cuda_volume_rendering.py and make a similar should suffice.  You'll need to link it through the appropriate .rst file (maybe complex_plots.rst?).  You can look at the other .py files in the cookbook to get an idea of formatting and such.

Lastly, you can try building the docs to see how your additions render before submitting by following these instructions: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/developing/building_the_docs.html .  

Thanks again for this awesome functionality!
content.html:
Writing docs is pretty straightforward. I just updated the documentation on how to do it in yt 3.0 here: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/developing/developing.html#how-to-write-documentation . The easiest way to write a doc is to look at a previous doc and use it as a template.

For documenting this new functionality, what I would do is just append your information at the end of the "visualizing/volume_rendering.rst" file. This file is somewhat out of date and is going to be updated soon, but this seems like the obvious location for you to describe your new methods. Just a short description of how to use this functionality and how it works.

Then, if you stick your example script (that you included above) in a cookbook recipe in the cookbook/ directory, perhaps call it cuda_volume_rendering.py and make a similar should suffice. You'll need to link it through the appropriate .rst file (maybe complex_plots.rst?). You can look at the other .py files in the cookbook to get an idea of formatting and such.

Lastly, you can try building the docs to see how your additions render before submitting by following these instructions: http://yt-project.org/docs/dev-3.0/developing/building_the_docs.html .

Thanks again for this awesome functionality!

content.raw: In general, cookbook recipes have documentation included in them as to what you are doing.  It's great that you're providing 4 different recipes to demonstrate how to use Theia, however, it would be better to have documentation as to what you're doing and how to use it, especially in the case with these super-long recipes where it is somewhat non-intuitive.
content.html: In general, cookbook recipes have documentation included in them as to what you are doing. It's great that you're providing 4 different recipes to demonstrate how to use Theia, however, it would be better to have documentation as to what you're doing and how to use it, especially in the case with these super-long recipes where it is somewhat non-intuitive.

content.raw: I think the narrative docs are good, but it might be worth documenting the recipes and cleaning them up a little since these are the public-facing documents on how to use the software.  Including a little description at the top of the recipe as to what it is doing and how it is going to do it would be useful, as well as some inline documentation so you can understand the general flow.

content.raw:
I sort of ran out of time with this. The opengl cookbooks are fairly obfuscated because opengl is obfuscated! I wanted to include them because I've never found a working example of PyCUDA/PyOpenGL interop online. These were intended as templates for further development.  I derived these from deprecated code. I didn't really intend Theia to be a frontend for users, but more of a backend tool for developers. So, the cookbooks I included were meant to be examples for -- "hey look how easy it is to stick Theia into these 'complicated' applications".

More importantly, there is a bug in the opengl examples due to changing the surface to uint32 (r,g,b,a). I spent some time debugging it, but still haven't resolved it. Maybe we should scrap the opengl examples for now?
content.html:
I sort of ran out of time with this. The opengl cookbooks are fairly obfuscated because opengl is obfuscated! I wanted to include them because I've never found a working example of PyCUDA/PyOpenGL interop online. These were intended as templates for further development. I derived these from deprecated code. I didn't really intend Theia to be a frontend for users, but more of a backend tool for developers. So, the cookbooks I included were meant to be examples for -- "hey look how easy it is to stick Theia into these 'complicated' applications".

More importantly, there is a bug in the opengl examples due to changing the surface to uint32 (r,g,b,a). I spent some time debugging it, but still haven't resolved it. Maybe we should scrap the opengl examples for now?
